moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: The starting setup of the so called Sozin, not Scheveningen variation.
moves.7. Bg5: Another interesting game is 7.Bb3 follow GM Goran Kosanovic - GM Michael Roiz game with ended with brilliant queen sacrifice. See http://chesslodge.blogspot.com/2006/11/michael-roiz.html.
moves.7... Qa5: Since White is trying to dominate d5 square, why Black did join the battle by move the Queen to 5th rank, at the same time attacking White's Bishop.
moves.9. Nb3 Qg5: But Black now dominate the Black square and thread to dominate the open g file.
White take opportunity to connect the rook and secure the open d file.
moves.13... O-O-O 14. f3 Kb8: moving away from white square and protecting the a7 pawn.
moves.15. Kb1 Bg7 16. Qd2: White is trying to do a direct attack at queenside with his pieces standing in this area. Black is trying to counter attack via long diagonal, considering his weapon is a Bishop pair.
moves.16... Rdc8 17. Bd5 f5 18. Nf2: Other option is to keep the Knight still in the area with 18.Nc3 but ..Nb4! attacking bishop and open up the c8 Rook to exchange the c3 Knight.
moves.18... Qf6 19. c3 e6 20. Bc4 d5 21. Bb5 R: 23. cxd4 Nxd4 24. Bxd7 Nxb3 25. Qe2 Rc7
moves.23... e5 24. fxe5 Nxe5 25. Rdc1: this enable Black to start a combination attack lead to a mate. Another option is : 25. Qf4 Ka8 26. Bxd7 Rxd7 27. c5 d3 28. Qc1
moves.25... d3 26. Rc3 Bxb5: Open up a file for c8 rook.
moves.27. cxb5 Nc4 28. Qf4+ Ka8 29. Nd1 Nxb2: and final Knight sacrifice. White resign seeing unable to hold the passed pawn or being mated.  30. Rxc8+ Rxc8 31. Qh4 Qe5 32. Qd4 Qxd4 33. Nxd4 Nc4

players: Lane, Gary W  vs. Williams, Simon K
